_prev_prog_3.Description: Mountain View Cold Storage has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program.  The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements.  At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119).  This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Mountain View Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter©, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Mountain View Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Mountain View Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name          | Process Chemical         | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration   Anhydrous Ammonia          40,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Mountain View Cold Storage has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overal

l plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Mountain View Cold Storage business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Mountain View Cold Storage employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.



1.2 Process Description



Mountain View Cold Storage operates a commercial cold storage facility in Reedley, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:



(5) Cold Storage Rooms

(4) Precool Rooms

(1) Loading Dock

(1) Summeripe Room 



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.



All control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within a refrigeration machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:

The flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted behind the bunker wall. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel and then to the high pressure receiver.



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.



There is ammonia detector installed inside the refrigeration machinery room. The sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate the mechanical ventilation system at a normal rate of 20 air changes per hour and activate an audible alarm and strobe. Also, a sampling system is installed in each refrigerated area th

at provides two-minute interval monitoring. The sampling system is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe.



An emergency control box is installed on the south exterior wall of the refrigeration machinery room, which contains four valves. The high side of the system has two valves that would discharge to atmosphere. The low side has one valve that would discharge to atmosphere. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system.



The ammonia system at Mountain View Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, the refrigeration system at Mountain View Cold Storage is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Mountain View Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Mountain View Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active logbook of all procedures and tr

ansactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Mountain View Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Mountain View Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Mountain View Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Mountain View Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Mountain View Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Mountain View Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Mountain View Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a r

esponsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Mountain View Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Mountain View Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Mountain View Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Mountain View Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
